channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: India Ink: Indian Nurses in Iraqi Hospital Wait for Violence to Subside
item.description: Forty-six nurses from Kerala are trapped in a hospital in Tikrit, Iraq, where they have been waiting since extremists seized the city on June 11.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies
item.dc:creator: By VISHNU VARMA

item.title: U.S. Asserts Self-Defense in Benghazi Suspect Case
item.description: The Obama administration told the United Nations that the suspected ringleader of attack on the American Consulate in Benghazi, Libya, was plotting more attacks on Americans.
item.dc:creator: By CHARLIE SAVAGE

item.title: Former Turkish Army Chief Is Convicted in 1980 Coup
item.description: The two former leaders were accused of setting the stage for an army intervention, then conducting the coup that resulted in widespread torture, arrests and deaths.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Ebola Deaths Rise as Outbreak Spreads
item.description: An Ebola outbreak continues to spread in three West African countries, with more than 330 deaths reported, the World Health Organization said Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Vatican: Pope to Beatify Korean Martyrs
item.description: Pope Francis will beatify 124 Korean martyrs and celebrate a Mass of peace and reconciliation on the war-divided peninsula during a visit to South Korea in August, the first papal trip to Asia in nearly 20 years.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Nigeria: Cause of Deadly Blast Unclear
item.description: Witnesses of a bombing that killed at least 14 people at a World Cup viewing site in northeast Nigeria blamed a suicide bomber driving a three-wheeled taxi, while a police official said Wednesday that the explosion had come from a parked car.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Mexico: Governor of Michoacán Resigns
item.description: The governor of Michoacán, one of the country’s most violent states, where people have taken up arms to fight drug and organized crime gangs, has resigned because of poor health
item.dc:creator: By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Asset Transparency Advocates to Be Sentenced
item.description: A court gave two days’ notice for the long-awaited sentencing of three prominent asset transparency advocates, family members said, with virtually none of the defendants’ lawyers able to attend.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrie for The New York Times

item.title: As Moderate Islamists Retreat, Extremists Surge Unchecked
item.description: In a reversal from the aftermath of the Arab Spring, elected Islamists are in frantic retreat across the Middle East and North Africa, and militants are on the march.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.media:description: Supporters of Egypt’s ousted president, Mohamed Morsi, during a military trial in March. In 2012, Mr. Morsi won Egypt’s first fair presidential election.

item.title: Insurgency in Iraq Widens Rivals’ Rift
item.description: After President Hassan Rouhani of Iran declared readiness to defend Iraq’s Shiite holy sites, Saudi leaders issued a barely veiled admonishment not to intervene.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE and DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:description: Iraqi Shiites brandished weapons and a poster of the Shiite cleric Grand Ayatollah Ali al-Sistani in Najaf on Tuesday to show support for the fight against Sunni militants.

item.title: Diplomatic Memo: Conflict in Iraq Adds New Angle to U.S.-Iran Nuclear Talks
item.description: Negotiators are growing skeptical that the United States and Iran can reach a permanent deal on Iran’s nuclear capabilities before a July 20 deadline.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER

item.title: Rebels Reject Ukrainian Leader’s Cease-Fire Idea
item.description: President Petro O. Poroshenko’s peace plan, which includes “decentralization” measures, came after a phone call with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW ROTH and DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: President Petro O. Poroshenko on Wednesday at a graduation ceremony at the National University of Defense of Ukraine in Kiev.

item.title: Uneasy Alliance Gives Insurgents an Edge in Iraq
item.description: Former loyalists of Saddam Hussein have been crucial in helping ISIS capture vast amounts of territory so quickly.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By TIM ARANGO

item.title: With World Cup in Headlines, a Debate Continues on What to Call the Game
item.description: A new academic paper suggests that the word soccer began in Britain and was used there happily until at least the 1970s, even as a spirited debate over the sport’s name endures.
item.dc:creator: By SARAH LYALL
item.media:description: A New York Times article from Oct. 22, 1905, used the term “Socker” in the headline.

item.title: A Retiree, 89, Is Held in Deaths at Auschwitz
item.description: The authorities charged Johann Breyer was complicit in the gassing of 216,000 Jews brought to Auschwitz in 1944 from Hungary, Czechoslovakia and Germany.
item.dc:creator: By ERIC LICHTBLAU
item.media:description: An undated photo of Johann Breyer, who was arrested on Tuesday and appeared in court on Wednesday.

item.title: Obama and Lawmakers Meet to Discuss Iraq Action
item.description: White House officials said the president did not rule out the possibility of coming to Congress for a vote to support his actions, depending on what he decides to do.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL D. SHEAR and MARK LANDLER

item.title: Dubai, Once a Humble Refueling Stop, Is Crossroad to the Globe
item.description: Dubai’s rise as a modern crossroads connecting East and West is a tale of globalization, ambition, and an audacious bet on the future of air travel that proved prescient.
item.dc:creator: By JAD MOUAWAD
item.media:description: Dubai’s airport includes soaring terminals, with water cascades and fake palm trees, duty-free stores and high-end boutiques.

item.title: Pressure Grows in Hunt for Kidnapped Israelis
item.description: President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority vowed to help catch whoever kidnapped three Israeli teenagers as mounting pressure threatened his reconciliation pact with Hamas.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN and ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:description: Israeli soldiers in the West Bank city of Hebron on Tuesday. The military broadened its search for three kidnapped teenagers, tightening checkpoints in Hebron and arresting 240 Palestinians.

item.title: For Vietnam and China, No Easing of Tensions
item.description: The two countries exchanged sharp views at a session in Hanoi to discuss a Chinese oil rig deployed in contested waters in the South China Sea.
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ

item.title: Japan Outlaws Possession of Child Pornography, but Comic Book Depictions Survive
item.description: The move brought Japan in line with the rest of the developed world, but Parliament left a loophole for the nation’s sometimes sexually explicit manga comics.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER

item.title: Drones Kill 5 as Pakistan and U.S. Target Tribal Belt
item.description: Those killed were in North Waziristan on Wednesday as the Pakistani military continued to fight terrorists there. It is unclear how much, if any, cooperation exists between American and Pakistani officials there.
item.dc:creator: By ISMAIL KHAN and DECLAN WALSH
item.media:description: A girl sat next to her belongings on a truck after arriving in Bannu, Pakistan, on Wednesday. About 90,000 residents have fled their homes to escape intense fighting in North Waziristan.

item.title: Leader’s Words About Women Jolt Morocco
item.description: Prime Minister Abdelilah Benkirane of Morocco told Parliament this week that women would be better off at home than in the workplace.
item.dc:creator: By AIDA ALAMI

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: China Keeps a Close Eye on Oil Interests in Iraq
item.description: As militants threaten to drag Iraq back into civil war, China National Petroleum Corporation, the largest state-owned energy company, anxiously monitors its substantial investments in the country.
item.category: Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By BREE FENG and EDWARD WONG
item.media:description: Excess gas burned off Al Ahdab oil field, which a unit of China National Petroleum Corporation is developing in a pact with Iraq.

item.title: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria? Or Islamic State in Iraq and the Levant?
item.description: There is no consensus on how to define the region denoted by the classical Arabic term “al-Sham,” which is part of the name of the group called the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria by many news outlets.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By PATRICK J. LYONS and MONA EL-NAGGAR

item.title: Candidate’s Protest Clouds Afghan Vote-Counting for President
item.description: Abdullah Abdullah accused his opponent, Ashraf Ghani, and President Hamid Karzai of fraud in the runoff vote, but the next steps are unclear.
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED and MATTHEW ROSENBERG
